2. The second training rule on receiving food

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme

original: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū bhuñjamānā sabbaṁ hatthaṁ mukhe pakkhipanti …pe….
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū bhuñjamānāḥ sabbam hattham mukhe pakkhipanti pe
translated: At that time the monks from the group of six put their whole hand in their mouth while eating. …

original: “Na bhuñjamāno sabbaṁ hatthaṁ mukhe pakkhipissāmīti sikkhā karaṇīyā”ti.
analyzed: na bhuñjamānaḥ sabbam hattham mukhe pakkhipissāmi iti sikkhā karaṇīyā ati
translated: “‘I will not put my whole hand in my mouth while eating,’ this is how you should train.”

original: Na bhuñjamānena sabbo hattho mukhe pakkhipitabbo.
analyzed: na bhuñjamānena sabbaḥ hatthaḥ mukhe pakkhipitabbaḥ
translated: One should not put one’s whole hand in one’s mouth while eating.

original: Yo anādariyaṁ paṭicca bhuñjamāno sabbaṁ hatthaṁ mukhe pakkhipati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.🔽Anāpatti—
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam paṭicca bhuñjamānaḥ sabbam hattham mukhe pakkhipati āpatti dukkaṭassa  anāpatti
translated: If a monk, out of disrespect, puts his whole hand in his mouth while eating, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
There is no offense if it is unintentional, if he is the first offender,
or if he is insane.🔽The second training rule is finished.
